fun fact
train heading due east (the speed makes no difference)
fruit fly heading due west on collision path.
theoretically speaking, the fly hitting the front of the train, stops the train.

not all at once, and only for the briefest period of time, but the whole train stops.

this happens because the fly is flying due west before impact, and is moving due east (splattered on the trains windscreen) after impact. we can logically deduce that the fly MUST HAVE STOPPED moving west before it could begin moving east with the train. this means the fly came to a COMPLETE STOP, for however short a period of time. the only reason it stopped is that it came into contact with the train. therefore, the fly was IN CONTACT with the train when IT WAS STOPPED or it would not have stopped.

now if one object is stationary, and another object is in direct contact with that stationary object is it possible for the second object to be moving... and be in contact... or for the contact to exist with a stationary object, do you not need to be stationary? try it yourself; hold your hands out as if praying, (christian way) now, keeping your left hand perfectly still, can you move your right hand anywhere without either breaking contact or moving your left hand...?

and you can say that the fly would just squash, but the fly is made of physical objects, regardless how small. you can take it down to atom on atom impact, the theory is still the same.

so a fly can stop a train. and for that matter, all impacts cause direct stops. when your driving into oncoming rain, when your jogging into oncoming air particles. you actually stop every time anything hits you... mindblowing right...?
